classes.name: Chaos Mage
classes.desc: Who is in control, chaos or the magician? . . . Someone is in control, right?
classes.complexity: At least as complicated as the core wizard.
classes.playstyle: Of all the classes, the Chaos Mage is the MOST defined by the Icons of a setting. The hardest part of playing a chaos mage may be that you're not going to be able to write all your options down on a character sheet. The price of a rich randomness of spells is that you'll need to keep the book around. The easy part of playing a chaos mage is that you have a limited set of options on any given turn. You don't have to compare more than two or three spell choices each turn, and most of these options have different usage patterns. In some cases the significant decisions you'll make will be how to put yourself in the best position for the spell you're going to cast and then how to use the choices within the spell. Playing a chaos mage won't prepare a newcomer to play any other spellcaster, but new players who enjoy shaping a path out of randomness should have fun. Just be mindful of other players.

keymechanics.title: Common Spell Roster
keymechanics.desc: Chaos Mages are unique in that they have access to every spell on their list, however they do not choose the spell they cast. You do decide whether you use a 1/battle spell or if you'll stick with an at-will.

keymechanics.title: Chaos Magic Categories
keymechanics.desc: Chaos Mage spells fall into offensive, defensive, or iconic categories, and the spell you cast is determined by chance. There are various methods to determine it. The best usage is to use a bag with tokens. For now, we will use a D6. 1-2: attack, 3-4: defense, 5-6: iconic. However, once you roll a result, ignore it until one result remains. For example, if roll a 3, ignore future 3s until only one result of the d6 is valid. You determine the spell you can cast that turn at the beginning of your turn, allowing you to act in a way to best use that spell.

keymechanics.title: High Weirdness
keymechanics.desc: Optional, but essentially functions like the Wild Magic chart for 5e Wild Sorcerers.

keymechanics.title: Enough Already! (Adventurer Feat)
keymechanics.desc: This is a feat party members of a Chaos Mage have access to. Once per battle you negate a High Weirdness effect.

powers.pwrDesc: Suitable for Chaos Mages with high Wisdom. When you cast a defensive spell, roll a d6 and add an additional effect to the spell.
At the beginning of each arc, you select a random Wizard spell that you are of a level capable of casting.

pwrFeats.feat: Gives you a random Wizard talent as well, gives you access to Utility Spell, gives you a reroll of you don't like the randomly picked spell.

powers.pwrDesc: Inflict damage and a random condition on the 1d6 enemies.
The next natural odd attack roll of an ally that hits deals extra damage.

pwrFeats.feat: Improves the damage and extends the effect. Feats requires Blood of Warriors feat

classes.backgrounds: Blossoming witch, jester, Demonic sacrifice survivor, fireworks exhibitionist, no-longer-frustrated librarian, stirge wrangler, Mythic Age re-enactor, Witchwood patroller, living spell, living dungeon denizen, wandering musician, hero from another Cycle.

classes.name: Commander
classes.desc: Some people are born to fight. Others like giving orders. Put these two types of people together and you've got a commander.
classes.complexity: At least as complicated as the core wizard.
classes.playstyle: The commander aims to tell other player characters what to do without interfering too often in the turn-by-turn structure of the round. That's why commands take effect on the turn of an ally who is already taking their turn. Tactics are usually used on the commander's turn, but they're limited by how many times they can be used each day. Choosing how and when you'll spend command points to help your allies may be challenging for a novice player.

keymechanics.title: Commands & Command Points
keymechanics.desc: All commands are at-will powers and you start each battle with 1 command point. You gain them by using your action to gain more or when you hit. For most commands, you use your interrupt action to aid an ally on their turn.

keymechanics.title: Tactics
keymechanics.desc: Powerful abilities you can use on your turn for immediate effect.

powers.pwrDesc: At the start of each battle a number of your allies get to add a bonus to initiative or a bonus to AC during the first round (your choice for the group).

pwrFeats.feat: Allow you to give you the bonuses to defenses and AC, or eventually both bonuses.

powers.pwrDesc: Allows you to let an ally rally for free (spend a recovery). And you can spend extra command point to bring up unconscious allies.
You turn the escalation die into a d8 instead of a d6 and have a 50% chance increase it by 1.

pwrFeats.feat: Gives you command points when escalation die maxes out again.

classes.backgrounds: Historical re-enactor, sergeant of the city guard, street gang survivor, ex-gladiator, wilderness scout, cobbler, bouncer, exotic dancer, Queen's Wood patroller, wargame veteran, Imperial squad leader, reformed drunk, and officer of the Sunguard.

classes.name: Demonologist
classes.desc: There's a new type of magician surfacing after the arrival of the Last Night who might do something about the world's demon incursions. It may not be something good.
classes.complexity: At least as complicated as the core wizard. With a bit of help from the GM, this is also acceptable for beginners.
classes.playstyle: Your experience as a demonologist depends on which path you've chosen. As a devotee of the path of corruption or the path of flame, you'll function somewhat like other spellcasters, preferring to keep allies, or your summoned demon, between you and the enemy. If you've focused on the path of slaughter, you're more likely to carry a serious melee weapon and welcome enemies who seek to engage you as unwilling sacrifices! This class can be fun for players who like to figure out interesting combos from disparate approaches.  Overall, there are some drawbacks to the abilities of the Demonologist and feats that would eliminate the drawback for another class just reduce it for the demonologist. This is by design, you're playing with fire you might get burned.

keymechanics.title: Initiate, Devotee, Fanatic
keymechanics.desc: Demonologist talents are grouped into three paths: Corruption, Flame, and Slaughter. Depending on how many of your three talents are in each path you're an Initiate, Devotee, or Fanatic of that path. The further down a path you are the more improved your powers and spells provided by that path will be, but your options will be narrower. These are essentially subclasses that you can pick and choose from.

keymechanics.title: Curse Spells
keymechanics.desc: These are a category of spells that don't have an effect when cast, but their effect occurs when a certain trigger condition is met.

keymechanics.title: Demon Summoner
keymechanics.desc: The demons you summon are, on average, stronger than the summons of other classes and don't require your action to control, but they take unpreventable damage taken at the end of their turns. Additionally, when a demon drops to 0 hit points, there is a chance it breaks free and acts of its own accord. Feats improve the demon's overall effectiveness in combat.

powers.pwrDesc: You can use a number of times per arc equal to your Constution modifier. When a creature fails a save from an effect of yours and drops to 0 hit points, a nearby enemy under the hit point threshold recieves the negative effect.

pwrFeats.feat: Gives more use when the escalation is high and makes the save effect passed to an enemy more difficult to resist.

powers.pwrDesc: You summon a giant flaming claw you can ride into battle. The claw offers an attack and improves your defenses.

pwrFeats.feat: Let you use it more with certain Icon relationships as well as if you are a path of flame devotee.

powers.pwrtitle: Blood for Blood! (9th level spell: Slaughter)
powers.pwrDesc: Deal damage to yourself and automatically critically hit your next melee attack.

classes.backgrounds: escaped sacrifice, child of cultists, survivor of a demon attack, survivor of an Iron Marshall attack, born of a demon incursion, former clergy for the Prismatic Gods, once-promising student at a Heartlands college, decorated soldier, respected doctor at an Idresan hospital, resurrected ancient hero, demon-child.

classes.name: Druid
classes.desc: Druids are poised between the cycles of nature and the timelines of civilization. It's true that druids are attuned to the calm rhythms of natural creation, but as mortal humanoids they're also poised between the savagery of wild nature and the mercilessness of tribal warfare.
classes.complexity: At least as complicated as the core wizard.
classes.playstyle: Depending on your talents, you can play as the Wild Wood's answer to the wizard, or as a warrior healer flourishing in the space traditionally defined by the cleric, or as a spellcasting magician who shapeshifts into animal forms to scout and fight. Your choice of talents is key, because each druid talent unlocks a pool of spells or powers. You also have the choice of doubling up on one of your talents, spending two talents instead of one to be more focused on what the talent has to offer. Druids are not the best characters for new players who want something easy to play.

keymechanics.title: Druidic Summoning
keymechanics.desc: Allows you to summon a minion or group of mooks to fight with you. Only one is active at a time. All summoned creatures take their turn right after yours in initiative (even if your initiative changes) and get the usual standard action, quick action, and movement action. Feats increase the effectiveness of your summons.

keymechanics.title: Initiate or Adept?
keymechanics.desc: You have three talent choices, you can put one in each of three gaining Initiate status in each or put two choices into a single option become an Adept in one talent and an Initiate in another. Adept status in a talent gives you improved and more powerful options from it.

powers.pwrDesc: Initiates get a limited number of Shifts into Scout forms (small, noncombat animals), Beast forms (combat animals), and Beast Form Aspects (powers that you use while in beast form). Adepts get Beast form at will and the other daily powers more often.

pwrFeats.feat: There are feats for Scout forms in total, and Beast Form attacks, as well as improvements to Aspects.

powers.pwrDesc: Turn an area dangerous to move through. The creature must make a save or take 7d10 damage. Allies get a lesser save and only take half damage.
You can only cast this spell once per level. You absolutely destroy a structure as if it aged centuries in minutes. It may take up to an hour to collapse complete.

classes.backgrounds: Orc-tribe hunter/gatherer, avalanche prophet, wild cult zealot, river guide, Elk Tribe healer, failed shaman, escaped demon gardener, wild temple priest, elven urban planner, mystic waterfall guardian, seventh initiate of the Stalking Trees Circle, and raised by wolverines.

classes.name: Monk
classes.desc: Every monk that joins an adventuring party has a story about why they are not back at the monastery. Some chase a vision, while others have been driven out. For some, it's a temporary step in their training. For others, it's a permanent exile. And for a very few, a hard-won escape.
classes.complexity: At least as complicated as the core wizard. With a bit of help from the GM, this is also acceptable for beginners.
classes.playstyle: Monks are great fun for experienced players who like juggling significant decisions within the flow of moment-by-moment roleplaying. You'll make significant decisions when building your character out of interwoven options and fighting round-by-round using the diverse elements of the monk's attack forms. Some inexperienced players can handle playing a monk, others can't.

keymechanics.title: Jab, Punch, and Kick Attacks
keymechanics.desc: Monk attacks are rated as Jabs, Punches, or Kicks. They have different base damage and in short your unarmed strikes are able to deal as much damage as a weapon. All monk attacks that use Dexterity as to hit, still use Strength for damage.

keymechanics.title: Forms
keymechanics.desc: Forms have an opening attack, flow attack, and finishing attack. You use the abilities in a particular order to gain their effect. Your first attack in a battle must be opening, then second must be a flow, then you can use a finishing attack or use another opening attack of a different form. After a finishing attack you must use an opening attack.

keymechanics.title: Ki
keymechanics.desc: You gain 1 + Wisdom modifier Ki per arc. You use Ki to shift the natural roll of your dice. So if you rolled a natural 19, you could spend 1 Ki point to turn it into a natural 20 and crit. Feats give you more ki and expand the usage during your turn.

powers.pwrDesc: If you use Flurry, you can't use another Seven Deadly Secret that battle. When escalation is 3+_, you get to attack with a Jab attack as a quick action.

pwrFeats.feat: Reduces the escalation needed to use Flurry and makes it more effective an attack.

powers.pwrtitle: Disciple of the Hidden Flame (Champion Talent)
powers.pwrDesc: Choose a cleric, sorcerer or wizard class. Choose a non-feature spell of your level or lower. You can cast the spell for free as part of a flow attack if at-will or with a finishing attack if it has a limited use (1/arc, 1/battle, etc). You can use Ki to access feats for that spell, if it has any.

Your openning allows you to engage as part of the attack. Flow attack allows you to disengage on a natural even roll. Finishing attack expands crit ranges on your attacks for the rest of the battle if you miss.

pwrFeats.feat: You can spend ki to disengage as a free action.

powers.pwrDesc: Your openning attack deals ongoing unholy damage on a natural even hit. The flow attack stuns the target if it has fewer than 180hp. The Finishing attack deals ongoing unholy energy and on a natural even hit, until the end of your next turn, you gain Flight, Resist Damage 16+ (you take half damage on natural attack rolls that hit but are less than 16) and become incorporeal.

pwrFeats.feat: Once per arc when you hit with a finishing attack, you can spend ki to make a link and can hit the target no matter how far it is until you run out of ki.

classes.backgrounds: Temple acolyte, mountain sanctuary guardsman, traveling circus acrobat, river guide, Cathedral runner, spider-cult assassin, tunnel vermin exterminator, bodyguard, farmer, hallucinogenic mushroom farmer, wild mountain ginseng harvester, traveling tournament organizer, Uthkril civil rights organizer, star pupil of the Court of Stars.

classes.name: Necromancer
classes.desc: Can dark magic be used for positive ends? Are there sacrifices that are too great, no matter what the reward? Is that skeleton someone you used to know?
classes.complexity: Of the supplemental classes, the necromancer often works for beginners.
classes.playstyle: Some of your talent powers and spells are straightforward, while others require weighing the odds whether they will hurt your enemies more than they will hurt you and your friends. There are sacrifices to choose—power that has to be paid for somehow.

keymechanics.title: Summoning
keymechanics.desc: Allows you to summon a minion or group of mooks to fight with you. Only one is active at a time. All summoned creatures take their turn right after yours in initiative (even if your initiative changes) and get the usual standard action, quick action, and movement action. Feats increase the effectiveness of your summons.

keymechanics.title: Wasting Away
keymechanics.desc: All necromancers are rotting away a bit, you must subtract your Constitution modifier from your necromancer spell attacks if it's a positive modifier. However, it takes an additional Skull (dropping to 0 or failed death saves) to kill you instead of five. Feats add benefits to offset having a negative Consitution modifier and make you harder to kill.

keymechanics.title: Ritual Casting
keymechanics.desc: Essentially allows you to spend one of your limited use spells in order to cast a utility spell over the course of a time period that is out of combat.

powers.pwrDesc: The first 5 or 6 you get on an Icon roll will automatically trigger a twist, however you also get an additional Necromancer spell.

pwrFeats.feat: All your Icon 5s and 6s trigger a twist, but you get an addtional Necromancer spell.

powers.pwrDesc: The undead you summon are truly released from your service when they drop to 0 hit points, and so they fight much harder for you. When an undead you summoned drops to 0 hit points, it releases holy damage to engaged enemies.

pwrFeats.feat: Improve the capabilities of your loyal, radiant undead.

powers.pwrDesc: Create 1d3+1 undead mooks (weak creatures who's total health is tracked as a group)

pwrFeats.feat: You can summon more mooks or if they survive they stay until the next battle.

powers.pwrDesc: A target under the hit point threshold just drops to 0 hit points and dies.

classes.name: The Occultist
classes.desc: Due to the narrative implications of the Occultist, as written, being the single one in the entire setting, for the time being, this class is not usable for Myrr.
